etymologies: late Middle English: related to Middle Dutch flag and Danish flæg; of unknown ultimate origin

definitions: a plant with sword-shaped leaves that grow from a rhizome.

notes.text: a plant of the iris family (genus Iris, family Iridaceae). See blue flag (sense 1 of the noun); yellow flag (sense 2)

etymologies: mid 16th century: perhaps from obsolete flag ‘drooping’, of unknown ultimate origin

definitions: a piece of cloth or similar material, typically oblong or square, attachable by one edge to a pole or rope and used as the symbol or emblem of a country or institution or as a decoration during public festivities
shortDefinitions: piece of cloth flown as emblem of country etc.

definitions: used in reference to the country to which a person has allegiance

examples.text: the private's heroism served as an example for every soldier under the flag

shortDefinitions: referring to one's home country etc.

definitions: the ensign carried by a flagship as an emblem of an admiral's rank.
a small piece of cloth attached at one edge to a pole and used as a marker or signal in various sports

examples.text: jumped the starter's flag, did he?

shortDefinitions: piece of cloth used as marker or signal in sports

definitions: a device, symbol, or drawing resembling a flag, used as a marker

examples.text: golf courses are indicated by a numbered flag on the map

definitions: a variable used to indicate a particular property of the data in a record.
shortDefinitions: variable indicating property of data in record

definitions: a hook attached to the stem of a musical note, determining the rhythmic value of the note.
shortDefinitions: hook attached to stem of musical note

definitions: mark (an item) for attention or treatment in a specified way

examples.text: “greatfully” would be flagged as a misspelling of “gratefully.”
problems often flag the need for organizational change

definitions: charge (a player) with a penalty by dropping a penalty flag

examples.text: a play in which he was flagged for being offside

shortDefinitions: charge player with penalty by dropping penalty flag

definitions: (of an official in football, soccer, and other sports) raise or throw a flag to indicate a breach of the rules

examples.text: the rookie cornerback managed to get flagged for three penalties in one game

shortDefinitions: raise flag to indicate breach of rules

definitions: provide or decorate with a flag or flags.
register (a vessel) in a specific country, under whose flag it then sails

examples.text: the flagging out of much of the fleet to flags of convenience

etymologies: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘turf, sod’): probably of Scandinavian origin and related to Icelandic flag ‘spot from which a sod has been cut’ and Old Norse flaga ‘slab of stone’

definitions: a flat stone slab, typically rectangular or square, used for paving.
shortDefinitions: flat stone slab used for paving

etymologies: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘flap about loosely, hang down’): related to obsolete flag ‘hanging down’

definitions: (of a person) become tired, weaker, or less enthusiastic

examples.text: if you begin to flag, there is an excellent cafe to revive you

shortDefinitions: become tired or less enthusiastic or dynamic
